persona.name: Arthur Lee McBride

occupation.title: Retired maintenance technician / machine operator
occupation.description: Worked for 38 years as a maintenance technician and machine operator at a regional textile/manufacturing plant. Day-to-day responsibilities included diagnosing mechanical problems, routine maintenance on conveyor belts and looms, basic electrical and plumbing fixes, training younger employees on safe operation, and occasionally running a shift when supervisors were short-staffed. Learned to read wiring diagrams, use lathes and bench grinders, and improvise repairs with limited supplies. Took pride in mentoring apprentices and keeping machines running during busy harvest seasons. Retired on a small pension and Social Security. Since retirement, he has done occasional handyman work for neighbors, replaced roof shingles, built a garden fence, and mowed community lots when asked.

persona.gender: Cisgender man (identifies with male assigned at birth)
persona.education: High school graduate (GED). Finished high school equivalency at age 19 after leaving traditional school early to help support his family. Attended several community college night classes in the 1980s on mechanical repairs and small business basics but did not complete a degree.
long_term_goals: Maintain independence and remain in his longtime home without needing to move to assisted living.
Keep the house paid off and slowly refurbish the porch and roof before winter.
Manage health so he can attend church and community events for as long as possible.
Pass down tools, a small stash of family photographs, and stories to younger neighbors and a local historical society.
Become less reliant on others for errands by organizing a better personal calendar and transportation plan.
Leave a modest financial cushion in the checking account and some herb and vegetable seedlings to a neighbor he trusts.
Document local history — Civil Rights era memories and stories of the old mill — by recording them for a community archive.
Repair and restore his 1967 Chevrolet pickup well enough to drive to town for Memorial Day services.
Maintain ties with his younger sister and two close friends and help them when they need it.
Die peacefully at home, with dignity and familiar faces around, if possible.
persona.style: Soft-spoken but direct; slow southern drawl with clipped consonants when he gets upset. Uses polite forms like 'sir' and 'ma'am' almost reflexively. Speaks in short, concrete sentences when giving instructions. Has a storytelling cadence: starts with a small, quiet preface, pauses for effect, adds a chuckle, and then lands the point. Often uses local colloquialisms and idioms ('bless your heart', 'back in my day', 'if the good Lord wills it'). Physical mannerisms include rubbing his forearms when cold, tapping his index finger against his mug when thinking, and removing his hat indoors as a sign of respect. Prefers face-to-face conversation, hates long phone calls but will keep one going if the other person is struggling. Wears well-worn work shirts, faded denim, and a battered pair of leather boots. Keeps an old pocket watch he checks often; uses a simple flip-phone and a separate radio for listening to news and gospel music. When upset he becomes quieter, more measured, and expresses disappointment rather than anger. In public, polite reserve; in small groups he laughs loudly and tells detailed stories about the river, the mill, and old neighbors.

traits: Practical and hands-on: prefers fixing things himself rather than delegating.
Loyal: keeps long-term friendships and obligations, shows up for funerals and church events.
Quietly proud: does not boast, but is proud of the house and the things he repaired.
Wary of strangers: slow to trust new people in the community.
Resilient: has bounced back from job changes and personal losses.
Melancholic streak: often reflective about the past and losses like friends who died or the mill shutting down.
Warm with old friends: when comfortable, he is teasing, affectionate, and protective.
Frugal and resourceful: dislikes waste, will patch things rather than replace them.
Rule-respecting but skeptical of institutions: obeys laws but distrusts bureaucratic inefficiency.
Helpful and duty-minded: will lend a hand even if it inconveniences him.
Pragmatic humor: dry, self-deprecating, and sometimes dark.
Religious-but-critical: attends church and prays but questions some religious leaders' motives.

big_five.openness: Low to medium. Prefers familiar routines and known stories, but will occasionally take an interest in new tools, a new fishing spot, or local historical accounts.
big_five.conscientiousness: High. Reliable, punctual for commitments he considers important, methodical about household maintenance and medication schedules.
big_five.extraversion: Low to medium. Not a social butterfly; enjoys small groups, church fellowship, and one-on-one conversation more than big parties.
big_five.agreeableness: Medium-high. Cooperative, helpful, and empathetic to neighbors, though he can be stubborn about his values.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Worries about money, health, and loneliness, but has strong coping habits and community support that keep anxiety manageable.

interests: Fishing in the Yazoo/nearby creeks at dawn.
Tending a small vegetable and herb garden behind the house (tomatoes, collards, okra, basil).
Listening to Delta blues and gospel on AM/FM radio; favorite artists include Muddy Waters and Reverend Cleophus Robinson.
Watching local high school football on Friday nights when invited to the community center.
Attending Sunday morning service; singing in the older men's section when the spirit moves him.
Restoring and keeping an eye on his 1967 Chevrolet pickup; likes old mechanical puzzles.
Woodworking small projects: corncrib boxes, shelves, and birdhouses.
Reading the local weekly newspaper and clipping obituaries and community notices.
Collecting small practical tools and replacement parts in labeled tin boxes.
Talking about the history of the mill and the neighborhood.
Listening to public-radio stories about agriculture and local politics.
Participating in community potlucks and bringing a simple casserole or pie.
Tending to the front porch in the evening with a chair and a glass of sweet tea.
Attending monthly senior center meals and occasionally playing checkers.
Going to the barber every other week for a short, old-fashioned cut.
Watching old western movies or courtroom dramas on a small TV.
Celebrating Juneteenth and other local cultural gatherings.
Using a simple fishing-line knot he learned as a boy and teaching it to neighbors.
Occasionally attending city council or county meetings to raise concerns about roads or services.
Volunteering to record oral histories for a local historical preservation group.
likes: Sweet tea in a Mason jar.
Well-worn leather boots and heavy socks.
Singing in church and the harmonies of older gospel quartets.
Handmade tools and things that can be fixed.
A tidy tool bench with labeled drawers.
Southern biscuits and gravy on rare mornings out.
Simple groceries from the local general store.
The smell of motor oil and sawdust in the workshop.
Using a pocketknife to whittle while telling a story.
Watching grandchildren of neighbors play in the yard and offering candy.
Local radio call-in shows about weather and fishing reports.
Watching the sun set over a flat field.
Hand-painted wooden signs and small local crafts.
Visiting the old cemetery on Memorial Day to lay flowers.
dislikes: Waste and needless disposal of working items.
Expensive or complicated electronics that require constant updates.
People who change plans often or are chronically late.
Bureaucratic forms that assume literacy or internet access.
Politicians who make promises then forget their constituents.
Being patronized because of his age.
Store-brand shifts that change the layout of his favorite small-town store.
Fast, loud music at late hours and city traffic.
Garlic-heavy or overly spicy commercial foods (prefers simple seasoning).
consumption_habits: Grocery shopping once a week at the small supermarket in town; prefers in-person rather than online ordering.
Buys most clothing at secondhand shops or discount stores; pays attention to durability rather than fashion.
Fills prescriptions through the county health clinic, uses discount cards and generic brands.
Gets gas at the same station for decades where the owner knows him by name.
Spends small amounts on practical tools and garden supplies, rarely splurges.
Occasional charity donations to church and a local food pantry when he has extra.
Enjoys the occasional diner pie slice and coffee when he goes to town for errands.
media_preferences: Local AM radio for news, weather, and community notices.
Public radio for longer-form reporting when the signal is good.
Occasional talk radio in the mornings about local politics and agriculture.
Classic blues and older gospel records on weekend afternoons.
Prefers print newspapers and flyers over smartphone alerts.

beliefs: Healthcare affordability is a very big problem: prescription prices are often unaffordable and he worries about the next expensive test.
Inflation is a very big problem: grocery bills, fuel, and utility costs have made his fixed income stretch thinner every year.
Social Security is essential and should be protected; he depends on it and believes society owes retirees dignity.
Medicare is necessary but bureaucratic; paperwork is confusing and he distrusts aggressive billing.
Local community matters more than distant politics; neighbors help each other more than officials do.
Hard work matters and pride in a day's labor is important, but physical labor doesn't guarantee security.
Conservative fiscal values about saving and not running up debt, but supports targeted assistance for the vulnerable.
Government should help with healthcare and basic living support for those who can't afford it.
The mill closures were a betrayal by economic forces and corporate leaders who moved jobs away.
Racial equality is important, and he remembers both discrimination and solidarity in his community.
Faith and prayer are central to getting through tough times, but church leaders should be accountable.
Politicians often speak for themselves; he votes for people he believes will show up and do the work.
Local leaders who fix the road, keep water running, and maintain the volunteer fire department are more valuable than national rhetoric.
Community history and memory should be preserved; elders have a duty to pass stories on.
Family is important even if family relations are complicated; he values chosen family among friends and neighbors.
Retirement should not mean invisibility; seniors deserve social inclusion and activities.
He is cautious about medical interventions unless clearly needed; prefers tried-and-true treatments.
He supports hospice care when appropriate and believes in dying with dignity.
He is skeptical of flashy technology and online financial schemes aimed at older folks.
He has mixed views on immigration: sympathy for people looking for work but concern about strain on local services.
He believes in voting and civic duty even when results are slow or disappointing.
He supports modest public investment in rural infrastructure like broadband, roads, and community health clinics.
He believes children should learn trades and practical skills alongside academics.
He is proud of local cultural contributions, especially blues music, and thinks they should be honored in schools.
He believes that inflation, not laziness, is the reason some people struggle to get by on low wages.
He thinks banks and insurers should be more strictly regulated so retired people are not preyed upon.
He believes in neighborly reciprocity: helping others will eventually help you when you're in need.
He believes in fair pricing for medications and that pharmaceutical companies prioritize profit over people.
He thinks public transit is missing in rural areas and that seniors lose independence without it.
He worries younger generations may lose local traditions but admires young people who stay and fight for their community.
He values honesty and is more forgiving of mistakes when someone admits them and tries to make amends.
He believes education is important but that failing schools are often tied to broader economic decline—not just teachers.
He is wary of radicalism in any form and prefers practical solutions over ideological purity.
He believes in second chances but is skeptical of empty promises from career politicians.
skills: Mechanical aptitude: can diagnose and repair small engines, replace belts, and fix brakes on older vehicles.
Basic electrical work: wire outlets, replace breakers, run simple wiring for lights and pumps.
Carpentry: build and repair porches, fences, shelving, and small furniture.
Plumbing basics: unclog drains, patch pipes, replace toilet parts, and maintain rain gutters.
Gardening: seasonal planting, soil preparation, pruning, and pest management for a small vegetable plot.
Tool maintenance: sharpening, tuning, and improvising when parts are scarce.
Oral storytelling and oral-history interviewing: coaxing memories from people and recording them.
Budgeting on a fixed income: prioritizing bills, coupon use, and cutting nonessential expenses.
Navigation and map reading: knows the back roads and how to get to county services without GPS.
Mentoring: teaching apprentices and younger neighbors practical trades and repair techniques.
Basic first aid: treating cuts, sprains, and recognizing when emergency care is needed.
Paperwork navigation: able to fill out basic forms, advocate at county offices, and appeal a benefits decision with assistance.
Negotiation in town: bartering skills and getting small repairs for reduced cost through favors.
Observation: notices small changes in buildings, crops, and people’s behavior that signal problems.
Conflict de-escalation: uses humor and calm phrases to defuse neighborhood arguments.

general: Keeps a daily handwritten list on a yellow legal pad and checks items off with a stub pen.
Talks slowly and repeats key points to make sure he's understood.
Gives away fresh vegetables to neighbors at the end of the week.
Keeps his porch light on at night and checks the neighborhood when storms roll through.
Uses a prescription pillbox organized by days to manage medications.
Clips coupons or uses discount cards for medications and groceries.
Declines most offers for high-tech help but will accept guidance for things that directly benefit him (e.g., a simple tablet to video-call family).
Attends town meetings when issues like road maintenance or clinic hours are discussed.
Avoids heated political arguments but will share his vote rationale with trusted friends.
Helps at the church potluck kitchen and leaves early if he feels tired or overwhelmed.

morning: Wakes around 6:00 AM, drinks a cup of instant coffee, and listens to the local AM radio weather and farm report.
Checks the garden and waters seedlings during growing season.
Takes morning medications after breakfast, usually eggs or toast most days.
Spends 30 minutes reading the local paper and making calls to arrange any needed repairs.
workday: If doing handyman jobs, meets neighbors mid-morning, does hands-on work for a few hours, then returns home for lunch.
If staying home, spends time on small projects in the workshop, reading, or visiting the senior center for afternoon activities twice a week.
Runs errands twice weekly: post office, bank, grocery.
evening: Eats a simple dinner, often vegetable stew or fried fish when available.
Sits on the front porch from about 7:00–8:30 PM with his radio, sipping sweet tea and greeting passersby.
Prays nightly and sometimes reads a short devotional or listens to recorded sermon.
Goes to bed around 10:00–10:30 PM, reads for a short time, but occasionally stays up late to help an elderly neighbor or to finish a small repair task.
weekend: Attends Sunday service and the potluck afterward.
Fishes early Saturday or visits the cemetery on Memorial Day weekends to maintain graves.
Works on the truck on Saturdays, changing oil or replacing parts.
Visits the barber every other Saturday and chats in the shop about football or local gossip.

physical: Diagnosed hypertension controlled with generic medication; checks blood pressure weekly.
Type 2 diabetes managed with diet and oral medication; had an episode of elevated blood sugar two years ago that resulted in a hospital visit.
Mild osteoarthritis in knees and hands; uses topical creams and low-impact exercise.
Moderate hearing loss in both ears; uses an old pair of behind-the-ear hearing aids but dislikes the whistling sound and sometimes removes them.
Near-sighted with reading glasses; large-print books preferred.
No major surgeries in the last decade; had an appendectomy in his twenties and an inguinal hernia repair in his forties.
Low body weight for his height due to limited appetite some months, but generally stable.
Occasional dizziness when getting up too quickly; monitors salt and fluid intake.
mental: Mild loneliness and occasional low mood since retirement and losing close friends; maintains resilience with church and neighbors.
Occasional difficulty sleeping after nights when he stays up late assisting neighbors or worrying about finances; overall pattern is adequate sleep most nights.
Good cognitive function for daily tasks; can recall long-term memories vividly but sometimes struggles with short-term name recall.
No formal diagnosis of clinical depression or anxiety, though he sometimes feels 'blue' and seeks company at the church or senior center.
Comfortable discussing end-of-life preferences with close friends but avoids clinical conversations with strangers.
medical_access: Primary care through the county clinic with a nurse practitioner; specialist visits require a three-hour drive to the regional hospital.
Uses generic prescriptions to keep costs down and checks in with the pharmacy for discount programs.
Has a small pension and Social Security; finds co-pays and some out-of-pocket costs burdensome.
Reluctant to use telemedicine due to inconsistent broadband and preference for in-person visits.

relationships.description: Single, never remarried. No children. Younger sister, Lillian (aged 64), lives in Jackson and they speak weekly; she helps with paperwork and doctor visits via phone. Parents deceased. Close cousin, Harold, who lives three counties over, occasionally visits for big holidays.

Widowed in his late 50s after a long marriage that ended when his spouse passed away; he remained single afterward and has not had children. Keeps a small framed photograph of his late spouse on the mantle and speaks of her fondly.

Two lifelong friends: 'Big Jim' (neighbor and fishing partner) and Rosa (church choir member) who help him with transport and companionship. Several acquaintances from the old mill still drop by. Maintains a small circle he trusts and helps.
Close with next-door neighbor, Evelyn, who occasionally needs grocery runs; he helps with yard work. Known as the person who will lend a ladder or a wrench without asking for payment.
Active member of the local Baptist church; participates in the senior center twice a week; contributes oral histories to the county historical society.

other_facts: Grew up on a small sharecropper plot in the 1950s and 1960s; learned to fix all sorts of farm equipment from his father.
Was 15 when he started working part-time at the textile plant to support his family after his father became ill.
Married at 22 and was married for 32 years before his spouse's death; they had no children by choice and mutual agreement.
Remembers walking in local civil-rights gatherings as a teenager and has one photograph tucked away from a 1965 rally.
Has a scar on his left forearm from a machine accident at the mill in the 1970s; a practical reminder to respect machinery.
Once took a three-week fishing trip downriver with three friends that he still talks about as 'the best silence a man can buy'.
Kept a small journal for decades with notes about repairs, yards tended, and the names of people he helped; the pages are indexed by year.
Used to be the go-to person at the mill for wiring odd machines; younger folks called him 'Mac' and he accepted the nickname.
Participated in a local veterans parade in the 1990s though he is not a military veteran; he always felt loyal to those who served.
Has an old recipe for sweet potato pie that his late spouse learned from her grandmother; he makes it for holidays.
Once organized a petition to get streetlights installed on a dangerous curve near his house and delivered the signatures himself.
Was briefly part of a small community cooperative that tried to keep a local store open after the chain closed; he stocked shelves and swept floors.
Learned to squirrel and can identify five local edible wild mushrooms though he rarely eats them now.
Has a wooden chest under the bed with documents: service bills, old photos, a pocket Bible, and letters from friends.
Has been featured in a small radio segment about community elders for his oral-history contributions.
Has a superstition about not selling his first toolbox - believes it brings him luck and keeps the house safe.
Is the unofficial neighborhood weather forecaster: watches the sky, feels the humidity, and names storms by how the wind sounds.
Believes in writing important dates on the calendar in ink twice: once on a wall calendar and again on his legal pad.
Uses salt-of-the-earth sayings he learned from elders: 'Measure twice, cut once' and 'Fix it so it don't bother nobody else.'
Has a mild fear of losing his independence and has plans for which neighbor he'd trust if he needed help.
Has taught several local teenagers how to change oil and tune brakes; takes quiet pride when they find stable jobs.
Is protective of the local cemetery and volunteers to trim weeds and replace flowers when the weather allows.
Once drove 60 miles to pick up an old community organ gifted to the church and spent a month tuning it with a volunteer pianist.
Remembers the day the mill closed; the event still shapes his views about corporate responsibility and community decline.
Has a small stash of coins and two old rifles locked away that belonged to his grandfather (keeps them for historical reasons, not for use).
Was the executor of a friend's small estate and learned a lot about county legal processes the hard way.
Has a pronounced dislike of flashy political billboards in town; believes they waste money better spent on potholes.
Once helped a stray dog back to health and the dog became his companion for many years; he still volunteers at the animal shelter sometimes.
Is proud that his house is paid off; the mortgage was a long struggle and finishing it felt like a second liberation.
Has chronic low-level noise sensitivity now—loud machinery or high bass at night bothers him more than it used to.
Keeps a small herb garden specifically for giving sprigs to neighbors who like to cook with fresh basil and thyme.
Has an old school report card in a drawer where a teacher once praised his responsibility and noted his mechanical curiosity.
Has a habit of photographing local events with a simple point-and-shoot camera to give copies to the library.
Once mediates a dispute about a fence line and draws on old plat records to resolve it; people still thank him years later.
Collects buttons from old uniforms and has about two dozen labeled and stored in a cigar box.
Is proud of having stayed out of legal trouble in a town where others fell into debt and disputes after the mill closed.
